awd_titl_txt: Charge Localization and Transport at Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: Carbon-based (organic) electronics are light-weight and relatively inexpensive, but have been more difficult to realize commercially.  Their electrical performance depends crucially on how spread out electrical charges become at the interfaces between different materials.  However, the most common analyses report on properties through the bulk, overlooking the underlying reasons for both good and bad electrical behaviors.  This project employs a measurement technique that delivers information about how molecules are arranged at material interfaces and the number of molecules over which electrical charges are shared. The project focuses on materials that work well and then introduces defects that diminish their performance, monitoring the effect of these defects on conductivity and the number of molecules on which charges reside.  In parallel with these research directions, the research team designs and leads the chemistry activities at an annual three-day outreach event called University on the Prairie.  This program hosts 60 students (grades 6-11) from rural communities in the Midwest and introduces many of them to the role of chemistry in agriculture, energy conversion, and in many cases, begins the process by which they envision themselves studying science at a college level. 


Technical Description:  The extent of localization of electrical charges at material interfaces has an enormous influence on their mobility, yet there are few characterization methods applied to organic electronic films that are interface specific.  Of these surface specific approaches, only vibrational sum frequency generation has the ability to simultaneously report the molecular ordering and orientation as well as the extent of charge localization.  This project seeks to directly measure the influence of molecular packing and charge localization on the efficiency of charge transport at organic material interfaces.  The research team applies vibrational sum frequency generation spectroscopy to field-effect transistors constructed with a family of perylene diimide molecular films and observes the changes in interfacial structure, mobility, and localization as the molecular structure is varied.  They also introduce planar thickness gradients of dielectric materials between charge donor and acceptor layers to progressively decrease the extent of localization, while carrying out the same spectroscopic analysis.  Finally, photoinduced charge transfer is used to prepare charge delocalized states while vibrational sum frequency generation is performed.  Overall, the project identifies the role of charge localization in transport at organic thin film interfaces.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
The mobility of charge carriers at organic interfaces is defined by molecular structure in a very thin region that is difficult to characterize. The overriding goal of this project was to use interface-selective vibrational sum frequency generation (VSFG) to study molecular structure at these boundaries and to related it to charge localization in semiconductor films. Correlating these measurements with lateral charge transport efficiencies offers insight into the relationships between interfacial molecular structure and function.

 

One organic interface that was studied was that of alpha-sexithiophene (6T), a common organic semiconductor that deposits with a range of bulk structures. Carbon-carbon symmetric and asymmetric vibrations were measured since they are aligned to the short and long axes of the 6T molecule. FTIR and Raman spectroscopies were first used to assign the vibrational modes and then VSFG was applied using polarization control to determine molecular orientation and ordering. The data were collected from a film of 6T deposited with a thickness gradient from 10 nm down to less than 1 nm thick over a lateral distance of 25 mm.  Multilayer interference modeling developed in the PI’s lab allowed isolation of the spectra from different interfaces. The carefully calibrated VSFG data showed that only modes aligned to the short axis of 6T were VSFG active, precluding determination of the “twist” of the molecule relative to the surface, but not the relative tilt. The results showed that 6T undergoes two structural transitions during thin film growth.  First, a change in relative molecular orientation occurs at film thicknesses of tens of nanometers.  This phase transition had not been previously reported.  At even thinner film coatings, there is a change in 6T environment that induces a vibrational frequency shift of about 2.5 cm-1 for the molecules at the buried interface.  These structural changes are summarized in Figure 1. The results are consistent with previously reported phase transitions observed during ultrathin 6T coverage by grazing incidence X-ray reflectivity.

 

Using a similar approach, thin films of perylenediimide (PTCDI) were measured by VSFG on silica and alumina. In this case, different thicknesses of the organic semiconductor and oxide dielectrics were used with multilayer interference to determine the interfacial molecular structure.  It was determined that PTCDI sits on the silica surfaces more ordered and upright than it does on alumina. This interfacial orientation has a direct impact on the orbital overlap between adjacent molecules that enables them to conduct charge more efficiently.  All of these characteristics were consistent with the decrease in charge mobility on alumina due to a disordering effect from the higher polarity of the surface.  Thus, while some dielectrics are useful in creating devices that are more efficient in terms of their lower threshold voltages, surface treatments are still necessary to control interfacial structure and maintain adequate charge mobilities.

 

This project also advanced the VSFG technique with the use of a custom designed etalon with a small free spectral range that created two narrow band visible frequencies for use in the VSFG experiment. This enabled two VSFG spectra to be collected simultaneously with different polarization combinations, saving time and improving method fidelity. This approach introduced a notable decrease in the total laser power required to carry out VSFG studies and should enable other groups to perform this technique with more compact, lower power laser systems.

 

Using these technical advances, the interfacial structure of pentacene thin films were characterized to resolve a long-standing growth mechanism debate in the field. Pentacene molecules adopt two different packing arrangements: the kinetically favored thin-film phase (TFP) occurs at lower substrate temperatures and thinner deposition thicknesses relative to the thermodynamically stable bulk phase (BP). Bulk-sensitive techniques cannot differentiate between sequential phase growth (the “buried TFP” model) and co-deposition (the “co-nucleation” model). Both mechanisms are shown schematically in Figure 2.  Using VSFG paired with FTIR spectroscopy and X-ray scattering, we determine that co-nucleation of both phases at the interface is the dominant growth mechanism.

 

This project also supported broader impacts in the form of community outreach and education. The PI serves as the Director of the Energy and U show at the University of Minesota, an outreach event that serves ~10,000 students each year with exciting onstage demonstrations. In addition, the PI’s research group runs the chemistry track of the University on the Prairie program, bringing hands-on experimentation to >50 geographically isolated middle school students. Both of these outreach activities were paused during the 2020-21 pandemic, but are now back in motion for the coming years.

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2021
Modified by: Aaron M Massari

  • Figure 2. Proposed packing motifs of TFP (red) and BP (maroon) pentacene molecules upon an increase in temperature, where co-nucleation occurs (left) or the buried interface remains entirely composed of TFP (right).
